titleStmt.author: Lea Bäumler

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.head: Typology (Local)
div.p: Urban sedentary dialect of the qəltu-type

Mosul is the third largest city in Iraq. It flanks the Tigris River, its eastern districts partly occupying the area of the ancient Assyrian capital of Nineveh. Mosul Arabic is spoken by both the Muslim majority and the small Christian minority. The city also had a large Arabic-speaking Jewish community until the mid-1950s. It suffered severe damage during its occupation by the Islamic State (IS) from 2014-2017.

Despite Mosul's size and importance, its dialect has been under-researched. The Swiss linguist Albert Socin published a short description of the city's dialect in the 19th century (Socin 1882-1883). Jastrow (1979) offers a short introduction to the dialect's phonology, morphology, and syntax, including some texts with German translation. Czapkiewicz (1969) deals with nominal annexation (iḍāfa). Jastrow (2004) contains a text in the Christian dialect of the town and highlights some points regarding the differences between Mosul's Christian, Jewish, and Muslim dialects. Texts in the Jewish variety on food and dishes can be found in Jastrow (1991) and Jastrow (2005). The study on negation in Iraqi Arabic by Abu-Haidar (2002) also contains data from Mosul.
Al-Bakrī (1972) is a monolingual dictionary of the dialect of Mosul.
There are about 15 audio-files from Mosul in SemArch - Semitisches Tonarchiv: http://semarch.ub.uni-heidelberg.de/portal-ssr/
